HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 19, 1926

COACH WATCHES
INDIANS WORKOUT
Norman C. Keyes, Graduate Manager, and Coach Ray
Van Orman dropped in to witness a practice of the Haskell
Indian football team during a.
recent visit to Philadelphia.
This is one of the undefeated
elevens of the East. They are
fast, clever, and heavier than
any other eastern competitor.
There is a story that Roebuck,
260-pound tackle, who runs
the century in 10.2, threw the
Boston College end opposite
him bodily into a six-man interference to break up a play
going around his end.

The Musical Club will open what
promises to be its best season with
a concert and dance at the Church
of Prince of Peace, Walbrook and
Ilarnont Ayes., tonight. Members
of the Clubs, to say nothing of the
d
irectors and officers, are expectant1Y awaiting the rise of the curtain in
order to determine how favorably
the selections and their rendition
Will be received. The opening night
is always one of great excitement
beiiind the scenes, since everyone is

HOPKINS HEADS ATTEND
MEETING AT OHIO
COLLEGE
Drs. Goodnow and Ames Present At
Conference At Western
Reserve University

HUDGINS VARSITY
•CLUB PRESIDENT
William H. Hudgins, 1905,
was elected president of the
Varsity Club at the club's annual meeting last Friday night.
He succeeds Dr. George A.
Stewart.
The other officers elected
are: Vice-President-at-Large,
Robertson Griswold; VicePresident for Football, Horace Burrough; Vice-President
for Track, Dr. George A.
Stewart; Vice-President for
Lacrosse, Henry Baker.
A resolution was passed
during the meeting stating that
the Varsity Club should exercise more influence in the future with regard to team
schedules a committee, consisting of the Athletic Director, Graduate Manager and
one delegate from the club
for each sport was appointed
to supervise the making of
schedules.

President Frank J. Goodnow and
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, Dean of the
College Faculty, have just returned
from Cleveland where they attended
last week-end a conference of university heads, .held in conjunction
with th(- centennial celebration at
Western Reserve University.
The main part of the celebration,
similar to that held here in October,
was staged in the spring of this year.
The conference that President
Goodnow and Dr. Ames attended
was called by President Vinson of
Western Reserve to discuss the
problems. confronting Western Reserve and other universities, and the
plans for the growth of the Cleveland institution, which will be presented shortly to its trustees and
faculty.
The conference was divided into
three sessions, meeting on Friday
morning, Friday afternoon, and Saturday morning. At each session FROSH WIN TRACK MEET
BY A WIDE MARGIN;
four prepared papers on a chosen
• SCHIEDT STARS
subject were read.
The Junior College

HOPKINS GRIDDERS
PREPARE FOR RAVENS
Maryland Team Heavy Favorities
In Turkey Day Battle
STEVENS OLD LINERS' STAR
College Parkers Are Gaining
Experience Steadily
Beginning the season with a green
team, the University of Maryland
has gradually gained experience
and strength until they have produced a fast, aggressive eleven that
will be by far the favorite over
Johns Hopkins in the Thanksgiving Day game. Combining a fast,
heavy line with a choice of running or plunging backfields, they
should have the advantage in wet
or dry weather.

The subject of the discussion of
the first session was "The Junior
College and Its Relation to the University Above and the High School
Below It." This problem has a close
connection with the new plan at
Hopkins, as it provides for the abolishing of the first two years of college work in the present system. It
was brought out that there are over
two hundred junior colleges in the
country today.
One of the biggest problems that
Western Reserve faces was brought
out in this connection, stated Dr.
Ames. Over 5000 students graduate
each year from Cleveland high
schools, and a majority try to enter
the university in that city. The Dean
said that it was absolutely impossible for Western Reserve to accommodate that number. A plan was
proposed providing for the establishment of three junior colleges,
which would be a part of the university.

OUT OF THE DARK
The action of the Interfraternity Board in seeking to provide
itself with a constitution, that it may rightly discharge its duties,
is to be highly commended. In the past few years the Board has
been run on custom, the constitution having been lost some ten
years back. Only those most deeply versed in interfraternity lore
have been able to say just what was in keeping with the law and
what just outside of its pale. When supposed violations of the
customs were brought to light they were either dismissed or punished by a very light fine. If the fine did not meet the approval
of the convicted fraternity there was an appeal. The retrial consumed some more weeks, the matter was mulled over by the entire Board, interest in the case waned and the real issues were
lost sight of. The result was that the fine was probably reduced
to one dollar and the case dismissed without further reprimand.
The Interfraternity Board and its actions became the laughing stock of the campus. It ceased to exert effective control because of the general indifference paid to its findings and the spirit
of levity in which its actions were held. Fines were never collected and what was worse all records of them were lost. Such
was the miserable condition that the Board found itself in at
the beginning of this year:
Out of this maze of difficulties the Greeks are at last finding a way. The new constitution that is now being considered
has many things to recommend it, chief among which is the
method of trying all supposed violations of the law. A court of
unbiased judges is a distinct step forward in administering justice
for it does away with the vote of the remaining members of the
Board, the majority of whom know very little about the case and
yet in the end determine the decision, since they are in the majority. The judges will feel their positions of responsibility and
give deep thought to the problem that is before them.
Still another change has been made in eliminating ridiculously
low fines for serious offenses and replacing them with penalties
in proportion to the seriousness of the offense.
The NEws-LETTER heartily endorses this constitution for it
feels that only with the advent of strong laws, consistently enforced, will the day of one dollar fines and their accompanying
laughter be done away with and the affairs of the Greeks on this
campus be put on a stable basis.

Carl J. Doederlein

YES and NO
In the last couple of weeks we have taken the trouble to talk
to the former editor of this column and the present editor-inchief of the NEWS-LETTER about the "idea" of this column. As
a result we launch ourselves into the following:
It would seem after all that in order to succeed in a given
project that a plan or policy is incumbent upon the artisan or
artist. If you grant in the first place that success is good then it
readily follows that a plan is likewise good. We concede to the
worker his plan and place upon him the odious weight of policy.
Policy hinders and restricts and annihilates freedom—but undergraduates apparently when allowed freedom are, whether by
themselves or by an organization, incapable of producing in this
column material that is readable. We admit, without damage
to our vanity that the things that have appeared under "Yes and
No" of late are pointless, banal mouthings. We feel even less
complimentary about "Pourboire". The last at least shows a
spark, a feeble one to be sure, of antagonism or, if you will, of
competition. However, the "how" of raising the pitch of that
competition to a point that perhaps would produce readable work
is not too easy a question to answer.
As a historical note, the original concept of the NEWS-LETTER
was a purely "literary organ". Since that time the paper has
become a news medium. In granting this column the "idea"
was that of fostering again the literary spirit.
The term literary itself admits of so many interpretations
that it's difficult to approach a discussion of the field.
Let us begin by agreeing that all undergraduates are not
morons by a rather long way. Since that is true, there must be
some thought upon the campus. The expression of that thought
is in short the "idea" of this column.
Now, the getting of this thought down on paper seems a
difficult procedure. The two superficially obvious reasons seem
to be an over-worked condition or the feeling of incapability of
expression. Both of the foregoing reasons are in a great many
cases imaginary.
The scope of the work is almost limitless. We have an idea
that it should not revert to a series of melancholy dissertations,
nor on the other hand, degenerate to a comic strip, nor of petting
platitudes until they purr like epigrams.
Let us delve a little in examples. An issue or so ago we
sounded an appeal for a personal substantiation of happiness.
The result to the minute is nothing, except an idea we have in
our mind that we have many substantiations. The reasons given
from potential sources was that the ideas entertained were not
the conventional idea that one is supposed to have. To our mind
it is the very essence of happiness not to be puritanical or hidebound.
A cross section of undergraduate life we feel can only be
chronicled by a representation of what the undergraduate thinks.
It is patent that, unless we do admit of stupid passivity, no group
of people as large as this group at Hopkins all believe the same
thing. If you enjoy indulging in spirits to the point of getting
gloriously drunk, it is copy, if you enjoy shooting crap or ducks,
the why of the situation is interesting. In other words, personal
points of view are the most interesting reading to an intelligent
reading public, whatever their interests. The only thing we do
not want is a paper that moralizes about the value of a beautiful
dawn or the inspiration of music. If you enjoy it the reason
is sufficient. You are not bound to be everlastingly proving something to be good for every other human being. We want in this
column a stimulus to whatever thought that exists on the campus.
If you like to look at beautiful women say so and if his idea about
why doesn't gibe with yours the resultant reply would be interesting. We welcome your copy. Hand it to Mr. Meyers at the
Post Office for "Yes and No", Box 397. Parenthetically, the defeat
of this appeal seems to us flat admission of passive stupidity by
the student group.

AMERICA DRY COMPARED TO GERMANY
SAYS POLITICAL SCIENCE FELLOW
Continued from Page 1, Col. 3
interests are brought together to
drink beer and chat in the evening.
German fraternities are much larger than those of this country.
German students are by no means
favorable to prohibition. Dr. Schrader thinks that America appears
rather dry in comparison to Germany and Europe in general. He
then mentioned that he has only
been in this country about two
months. He thinks that in time local option in the provinces will succeed concerning prohibition.
Athletics are becoming very popular in Germany. In fact, athletic training is being substituted for
military training in many cases.
Water sports in particular are pop-

ular. In German universities every
one takes part in some athletic activity which is in marked contrast
to the American system. Fencing
is the national sport.
Dr. Schrader in discussing Germany's part in the World War
stated that the Armistice would not
have occurred as soon as it did were
it not for an internal revolution.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 19, 1926

THE ART

DORM DOINGS
Last Sunday evening in the Commons Rooms many enjoyed the selections played by a string orchestra composed of residents. Efforts
are being made to have concerts and
similar musical entertainments every Sunday evening. There is a
Wealth of musical talent in the dormitory and there should he little
difficulty in realizing this project.
Such entertainments will not be
necessarily limited to residents
alone.

MRS. B. P. WARREN

CLEANERS and DYERS

Scalp Treatment

2442 St. Paul St. cor. 25th St.

Tuesday morning the marble
. steps leading to the courtyard_ of
the dormitory appeared as an overkwing dam. The geometrically
laid paths leading to the entries
served as excellent drains.

C. R. HANNA

EVER heard of station
CRH",you'll say. Quite
naturally, for CRH is not a station. CRH is Clinton R. Hanna,
age 27, out of Purdue less than
five years, a Research Engineer
with Westinghouse at East
Pittsburgh.
Any time you're listening to
your radio, however, you may be
getting better reception, a clearer
program, because of CRH and
the improvements in reproducing apparatus to which he contributed.
That story goes back to undergraduate days at Lafayette.
Hanna, as a student, developed
an intense interest in radio; and,
making capital out of his hobby,
his thesis was entitled, "Interrupter Type of Radio. Transmitter."
To carry on his experiments,
it was logical that Hanna should
find his way into the Westinghouse Graduate Students'Course
immediately after graduation.
There he received varied practical
shop training. Then,in less than
a year, he was busily at work on

"What's thefuture with a
large organization?" That
is what college men want to know,
first of all. The question is hest
answered by the accomplishments
of others with similar training
and like opportunities. This is
one of a series of advertisements
portraying the progress at Westinghouse of typical college graduates, off the campus some five
—eight—ten years.

CC

his favored radio subject at the
Westinghouse Research Laboratories.
One of his accomplishments
has been the development of an
improved microphone. He has
introduced the electro-dynamic
principle, in place of the condenser-transmitter type of microphone in earlier use. Hanna's

development assures good quality
of speech and music with greater
continuity of operation than
other types, because of its ruggedness and sensitivity.
For this inventive spirit and
its resultin microphones,Hanna's
alma mater in 1926 honored him
with a degree of Electrical Engineer to go with his Bachelor
of Science degree of four years
earlier.
And these are studies which
still go on. There is no end to
progress. It is because Westinghouse offers both facilities and
appreciation for practical study
that Research Engineers find
satisfying careers in the Company's laboratories.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 19, 1926

COACH WATCHES
INDIANS WORKOUT
Norman C. Keyes, Graduate Manager, and Coach Ray
Van Orman dropped in to witness a practice of the Haskell
Indian football team during a.
recent visit to Philadelphia.
This is one of the undefeated
elevens of the East. They are
fast, clever, and heavier than
any other eastern competitor.
There is a story that Roebuck,
260-pound tackle, who runs
the century in 10.2, threw the
Boston College end opposite
him bodily into a six-man interference to break up a play
going around his end.

of Prince of Peace, Walbrook and
Ilarnont Ayes., tonight. Members

the selections and their rendition

is always one of great excitement

HOPKINS HEADS ATTEND
MEETING AT OHIO
COLLEGE
Drs. Goodnow and Ames Present At
Conference At Western
Reserve University

HUDGINS VARSITY
•CLUB PRESIDENT
William H. Hudgins, 1905,
was elected president of the
Varsity Club at the club's annual meeting last Friday night.
He succeeds Dr. George A.
Stewart.
The other officers elected
are: Vice-President-at-Large,
Robertson Griswold; VicePresident for Football, Horace Burrough; Vice-President
for Track, Dr. George A.
Stewart; Vice-President for
Lacrosse, Henry Baker.
A resolution was passed
during the meeting stating that
the Varsity Club should exercise more influence in the future with regard to team
schedules a committee, consisting of the Athletic Director, Graduate Manager and
one delegate from the club
for each sport was appointed
to supervise the making of
schedules.

President Frank J. Goodnow and
Dr. Joseph S. Ames, Dean of the
College Faculty, have just returned
from Cleveland where they attended
last week-end a conference of university heads, .held in conjunction
with th(- centennial celebration at
Western Reserve University.
The main part of the celebration,
similar to that held here in October,
was staged in the spring of this year.
The conference that President
Goodnow and Dr. Ames attended
was called by President Vinson of
Western Reserve to discuss the
problems. confronting Western Reserve and other universities, and the
plans for the growth of the Cleveland institution, which will be presented shortly to its trustees and
faculty.
The conference was divided into
three sessions, meeting on Friday
morning, Friday afternoon, and Saturday morning. At each session FROSH WIN TRACK MEET
BY A WIDE MARGIN;
four prepared papers on a chosen
• SCHIEDT STARS
subject were read.

Maryland Team Heavy Favorities

STEVENS OLD LINERS' STAR
College Parkers Are Gaining
Experience Steadily
Beginning the season with a green
team, the University of Maryland
has gradually gained experience
and strength until they have produced a fast, aggressive eleven that
will be by far the favorite over
Johns Hopkins in the Thanksgiving Day game. Combining a fast,
heavy line with a choice of running or plunging backfields, they
should have the advantage in wet
or dry weather.

The subject of the discussion of
the first session was "The Junior
College and Its Relation to the University Above and the High School
Below It." This problem has a close
connection with the new plan at
Hopkins, as it provides for the abolishing of the first two years of college work in the present system. It
was brought out that there are over
two hundred junior colleges in the
country today.
One of the biggest problems that
Western Reserve faces was brought
out in this connection, stated Dr.
Ames. Over 5000 students graduate
each year from Cleveland high
schools, and a majority try to enter
the university in that city. The Dean
said that it was absolutely impossible for Western Reserve to accommodate that number. A plan was
proposed providing for the establishment of three junior colleges,
which would be a part of the university.

OUT OF THE DARK
The action of the Interfraternity Board in seeking to provide
itself with a constitution, that it may rightly discharge its duties,
is to be highly commended. In the past few years the Board has
been run on custom, the constitution having been lost some ten
years back. Only those most deeply versed in interfraternity lore
have been able to say just what was in keeping with the law and
what just outside of its pale. When supposed violations of the
customs were brought to light they were either dismissed or punished by a very light fine. If the fine did not meet the approval
of the convicted fraternity there was an appeal. The retrial consumed some more weeks, the matter was mulled over by the entire Board, interest in the case waned and the real issues were
lost sight of. The result was that the fine was probably reduced
to one dollar and the case dismissed without further reprimand.
The Interfraternity Board and its actions became the laughing stock of the campus. It ceased to exert effective control because of the general indifference paid to its findings and the spirit
of levity in which its actions were held. Fines were never collected and what was worse all records of them were lost. Such
was the miserable condition that the Board found itself in at
the beginning of this year:
Out of this maze of difficulties the Greeks are at last finding a way. The new constitution that is now being considered
has many things to recommend it, chief among which is the
method of trying all supposed violations of the law. A court of
unbiased judges is a distinct step forward in administering justice
for it does away with the vote of the remaining members of the
Board, the majority of whom know very little about the case and
yet in the end determine the decision, since they are in the majority. The judges will feel their positions of responsibility and
give deep thought to the problem that is before them.
Still another change has been made in eliminating ridiculously
low fines for serious offenses and replacing them with penalties
in proportion to the seriousness of the offense.
The NEws-LETTER heartily endorses this constitution for it
feels that only with the advent of strong laws, consistently enforced, will the day of one dollar fines and their accompanying
laughter be done away with and the affairs of the Greeks on this
campus be put on a stable basis.

Carl J. Doederlein

YES and NO
In the last couple of weeks we have taken the trouble to talk
to the former editor of this column and the present editor-inchief of the NEWS-LETTER about the "idea" of this column. As
a result we launch ourselves into the following:
It would seem after all that in order to succeed in a given
project that a plan or policy is incumbent upon the artisan or
artist. If you grant in the first place that success is good then it
readily follows that a plan is likewise good. We concede to the
worker his plan and place upon him the odious weight of policy.
Policy hinders and restricts and annihilates freedom—but undergraduates apparently when allowed freedom are, whether by
themselves or by an organization, incapable of producing in this
column material that is readable. We admit, without damage
to our vanity that the things that have appeared under "Yes and
No" of late are pointless, banal mouthings. We feel even less
complimentary about "Pourboire". The last at least shows a
spark, a feeble one to be sure, of antagonism or, if you will, of
competition. However, the "how" of raising the pitch of that
competition to a point that perhaps would produce readable work
is not too easy a question to answer.
As a historical note, the original concept of the NEWS-LETTER
was a purely "literary organ". Since that time the paper has
become a news medium. In granting this column the "idea"
was that of fostering again the literary spirit.
The term literary itself admits of so many interpretations
that it's difficult to approach a discussion of the field.
Let us begin by agreeing that all undergraduates are not
morons by a rather long way. Since that is true, there must be
some thought upon the campus. The expression of that thought
is in short the "idea" of this column.
Now, the getting of this thought down on paper seems a
difficult procedure. The two superficially obvious reasons seem
to be an over-worked condition or the feeling of incapability of
expression. Both of the foregoing reasons are in a great many
cases imaginary.
The scope of the work is almost limitless. We have an idea
that it should not revert to a series of melancholy dissertations,
nor on the other hand, degenerate to a comic strip, nor of petting
platitudes until they purr like epigrams.
Let us delve a little in examples. An issue or so ago we
sounded an appeal for a personal substantiation of happiness.
The result to the minute is nothing, except an idea we have in
our mind that we have many substantiations. The reasons given
from potential sources was that the ideas entertained were not
the conventional idea that one is supposed to have. To our mind
it is the very essence of happiness not to be puritanical or hidebound.
A cross section of undergraduate life we feel can only be
chronicled by a representation of what the undergraduate thinks.
It is patent that, unless we do admit of stupid passivity, no group
of people as large as this group at Hopkins all believe the same
thing. If you enjoy indulging in spirits to the point of getting
gloriously drunk, it is copy, if you enjoy shooting crap or ducks,
the why of the situation is interesting. In other words, personal
points of view are the most interesting reading to an intelligent
reading public, whatever their interests. The only thing we do
not want is a paper that moralizes about the value of a beautiful
dawn or the inspiration of music. If you enjoy it the reason
is sufficient. You are not bound to be everlastingly proving something to be good for every other human being. We want in this
column a stimulus to whatever thought that exists on the campus.
If you like to look at beautiful women say so and if his idea about
why doesn't gibe with yours the resultant reply would be interesting. We welcome your copy. Hand it to Mr. Meyers at the
Post Office for "Yes and No", Box 397. Parenthetically, the defeat
of this appeal seems to us flat admission of passive stupidity by
the student group.

AMERICA DRY COMPARED TO GERMANY
SAYS POLITICAL SCIENCE FELLOW
Continued from Page 1, Col. 3
interests are brought together to
drink beer and chat in the evening.
German fraternities are much larger than those of this country.
German students are by no means
favorable to prohibition. Dr. Schrader thinks that America appears
rather dry in comparison to Germany and Europe in general. He
then mentioned that he has only
been in this country about two
months. He thinks that in time local option in the provinces will succeed concerning prohibition.
Athletics are becoming very popular in Germany. In fact, athletic training is being substituted for
military training in many cases.
Water sports in particular are pop-

ular. In German universities every
one takes part in some athletic activity which is in marked contrast
to the American system. Fencing
is the national sport.
Dr. Schrader in discussing Germany's part in the World War
stated that the Armistice would not
have occurred as soon as it did were
it not for an internal revolution.

THE ART

DORM DOINGS
Last Sunday evening in the Commons Rooms many enjoyed the selections played by a string orchestra composed of residents. Efforts
are being made to have concerts and
similar musical entertainments every Sunday evening. There is a
Wealth of musical talent in the dormitory and there should he little
difficulty in realizing this project.
Such entertainments will not be
necessarily limited to residents
alone.

C. R. HANNA

EVER heard of station
CRH",you'll say. Quite
naturally, for CRH is not a station. CRH is Clinton R. Hanna,
age 27, out of Purdue less than
five years, a Research Engineer
with Westinghouse at East
Pittsburgh.
Any time you're listening to
your radio, however, you may be
getting better reception, a clearer
program, because of CRH and
the improvements in reproducing apparatus to which he contributed.
That story goes back to undergraduate days at Lafayette.
Hanna, as a student, developed
an intense interest in radio; and,
making capital out of his hobby,
his thesis was entitled, "Interrupter Type of Radio. Transmitter."
To carry on his experiments,
it was logical that Hanna should
find his way into the Westinghouse Graduate Students'Course
immediately after graduation.
There he received varied practical
shop training. Then,in less than
a year, he was busily at work on

"What's thefuture with a
large organization?" That
is what college men want to know,
first of all. The question is hest
answered by the accomplishments
of others with similar training
and like opportunities. This is
one of a series of advertisements
portraying the progress at Westinghouse of typical college graduates, off the campus some five
—eight—ten years.

CC

his favored radio subject at the
Westinghouse Research Laboratories.
One of his accomplishments
has been the development of an
improved microphone. He has
introduced the electro-dynamic
principle, in place of the condenser-transmitter type of microphone in earlier use. Hanna's

development assures good quality
of speech and music with greater
continuity of operation than
other types, because of its ruggedness and sensitivity.
For this inventive spirit and
its resultin microphones,Hanna's
alma mater in 1926 honored him
with a degree of Electrical Engineer to go with his Bachelor
of Science degree of four years
earlier.
And these are studies which
still go on. There is no end to
progress. It is because Westinghouse offers both facilities and
appreciation for practical study
that Research Engineers find
satisfying careers in the Company's laboratories.

Westinghouse
